column2: Aarakocra are reclusive avians, who usually keep to their mountain eyries. But a few have found high places in the service of other cultures.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Auran
Aasimar are the descendants of celestials and deities of the upper planes. Many are renowned for good deeds, but some tread other paths...
Abeiran cultures originate on Toril's twin world of Abeir, separated from in aeons ago.
Aberrations are creatures whose biology and culture owes more to the influence of the mysterious Far Realm than to the Material Plane.
Aboleths are seemingly immortal fish-like beings with strange psychic powers and strange, alien agendas.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Abolethic
Abominations are among the strongest and most snake-like of the yuan-ti.\n§ZCourt Language§!: yuan-ti
The Affa people are the indigenous inhabitants of Afyal, the Isle of the Elephant.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Affa
Aglarondan culture emerged in the wake of the victory of the Yuirwood elves over Velprin. It is a hybrid culture, adhered to by many half-elves.
Air genasi, sometimes called windsouls, are people with ancestral ties to the Elemental Plane of Air, and its residents such as djinn.
The Akotans are a seafaring culture that trades extensively with Zakhara, Arandron and Katashaka.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
The Altumbelian people live on the tip of the Aglarondan peninsula and the islands beyond it in the Sea of Fallen Stars. They are often merchants or pirates.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Aglarondan
The Amaese people live in the icy Ama Basin in the far north of Kara-Tur.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Amaese
The Amaese people live in the icy Ama Basin in the far north of Kara-Tur.

Amethyst Dragons tend to be aloof philosophers who regard everyday moral problems as beneath their notice. They live in cool climates and can exhale a variety of weaponised forcefields.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic
Amnian culture is famously preoccupied with trade and commerce, which permeate Amnian people's idioms and daily lives.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorass
Aasimon are powerful celestials that are not tied to one specific outer plane, but can serve deities or other celestial groups as they see fit.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial
Archons are celestials from the Seven Heavens of Mount Celestia, dedicated to Law and Good.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial
Ardlings are a kind of aasimar, descended from deities or celestials, and possessing diverse animal-like features.
Arctic Dwarves are native to the very coldest mountains of Faerûn, especially in and around Pelvuria, the Great Glacier.\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dwarvish
The Arkaiun people have ancient ties to the far north of Faerûn, but have lived in the region of Dambrath in the Shining South for generations.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dambrathan
The Arnadar people live around the shores of Arnaden, otherwise known as the Lake of Steam.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Alzhedo\n§Y*§! Access to the Eldership succession if tribal.
Avorals are an avian variety of Guardinal, celestials from the Blessed Fields of Elysium.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial
Laerti, known to outsiders as Asabi, are desert-dwelling lizardfolk, well adapted to dry conditions such as those of Anauroch.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
The Aslanlar people, also known as the Lions of Arnaden, are nomads living in the inland territories north of the Lake of Steam.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Alzhedo
The Astok people are the indigenous inhabitants of the Furrowed Mountains of Zakhara.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
The Asuras are wild celestials who in ancient times quarelled with the Aasimon and went their own way, pursuing the cause of good solely by their own lights.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial
Avariel, or aril-tel-quessir, are winged elves who survived near-extinction in ancient wars against dragons.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish
The avian peoples of Faerûn are descended from the ancient Aearee creators, who vanished from Toril many ages ago.
The Azuposi are humans who live in the Pasocada Basin in Maztica.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Azuposi
The Baatezu are devils who live in the Nine Hells of Baator. They are dedicated to the spread of their own authoritarian political and religious system.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal
The Badia are nomads who live in the deserts of Zakhara.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
Bakemono are goblins who live in the wildest places of Kara-Tur.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ghukliak
Baphitaurs are abyssal planetouched minotaurs, said to be the product of demonic experimentation in the ancient magocracy of Netheril.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Abyssal
The Batiri are goblins who live in the jungles of the Chultan peninsula.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ghukliak
The Bawani are a maritime people native to the island of Bawa, in the Celestial Sea east of Kara-Tur.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Bawani
The Bedine trace their ancestry to pre-Enlightenment Zakhara, but have lived as nomads in Anauroch for countless generations.\n§Y*§! Access to the Eldership succession.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
Beholders are notorious aberrations, who are typically convinced of their own individual perfection as the peak of all living things.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Quevquel
Black dragons typically live in swamps and can spit acid. They are notorious for short tempers and cruelty.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic
Blue dragons, also known as storm dragons for their lightning breath, typically live in harsh desert climates and have a reputation as manipulative tricksters.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic
Bone nagas are nagas of other kinds which have been animated by necromantic magic after death.

Brass dragons live in barren deserts, and love to converse at length with their infrequent intelligent guests. If need be, they can exhale a cloud of potent soporific gas.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Bronze dragons dwell along exposed coastlines, but their varied breath weapons and powerful magical capabilities mean that they are often only encountered if they wish to be.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Brown dragons, also called sand dragons, are voracious hunters that live in deserts and scrublands. They can spit acid, and although they are generally antisocial, they are sometimes venerated by smaller creatures living alongside them.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Bugbears are large, hairy goblins with powerful clawed hands. They have a poor reputation, except with other goblins, but they have produced some renowned martial heroes over the years.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ghukliak\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
The Calishite culture is followed predominantly by humans and genasi living in Calimshan and the surrounding areas along the shores of the Shining Sea.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Alzhedo

The cultural history of Calimshan and its neighbours reaches back to old Coramshan and before, to the days of the genie empires of the Era of Skyfire. Many human and genasi cultures trace their ancestry to these civilisations and their successors in the Shoon Imperium.
Cervidals are guardinals, celestials from the Blessed Fields of Elysium, who have the heads and hooves of goats. They are fierce defenders of the innocent.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

Celestial eladrin are immortal planar creatures from the Shining Mountains of Arvandor. They superficially resemble elves, but have powers and awareness far beyond all but the mightiest of elvenkind.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

Celestials, sometimes also called angels, are powerful planar beings from the upper outer planes. Many remain in those blessed regions, but others have missions or callings that bring them to the material plane.
The Celestial Sea, to the east of Kara-Tur, is scattered with archipelagos and peninsulas that are home to maritime cultures quite distinct from those of the nearby mainland.

The creatures most often called centaurs, or more properly hippocentaurs, have the upper bodies of humans atop the shoulders and bodies of horses. They come in a range of sizes, and tend to live in plains and scattered forests where they can run free.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish
Centaurs are creatures characterised by humanoid torsos rising from the shoulders of animal bodies. Their cultures are varied, but tend to exist on the margins of other humanoid societies.

Chessenta was one of the Old Empires along the southern shores of the Sea of Fallen Stars, but for much of its history has been a group of city-states. Compared to its neighbours, its human-majority culture is characterised by a reverence for dragons and warriors, and a scholarly interest in magic.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chessentan
The Ch'ing are the native people of the Shou province of Ch'ing Tung. They are seen by their neighbours as adventurous and innovative, even to a fault.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou

Chondath and its neighbour Sespech are small nations on the shores of the Vilhon Reach, but as successors of the ancient psionic empire of Jhaamdath, they are representatives of a culture with widespread cultural and linguistic influence.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chondathan

The Chondathan cultures spread out around the Sea of Fallen Stars after the destruction of Jhaamdath by elven high magic. They are widely scattered now, which has led to the adoption of Chondathan languages as a form of Common Tongue.
The chromatic dragons are widely regarded as the cruelest and greediest of dragonkind, and many of them worship the dragon queen Tiamat.

The Chu are the people of the Shou province of Chu' Yuan, the Bamboo Plains. Their outlook has been shaped by generations of warfare between Shou Lung and the breakaway empire of T'u Lung, which have made them wary of outside influences.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou

The Chun cultures were a diverse range of civilisations in eastern and central Zakhara before the time of the First Caliph, united by their common Chun language. Since then, they have largely been eclipsed by the Badia and Hadhar.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chun

The Oigur are a traditionally nomadic ethnic group of the southern Hordelands. They are traditionally allies of the more widely scattered Gurs.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Oigur\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.
The Guychiang are a traditionally nomadic people from the Plain of Horses on the western frontier of Kara-Tur.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Zamogedi are a people of the northern Hordelands with a strong martial culture and marked disrespect for the settled peoples living on the margins of their territory.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Zamogedi\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Quirish are a nomadic people of the Hordelands with longstanding political and linguistic ties to the warlike Zamogedi and a rivalry with the Fankiang.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Quirish\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Fankiang are a nomadic people of the eastern Endless Waste. Many of them are sworn to an ancestral feud with the Commani.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.
The Kashghun are a nomadic culture of the Plain of Horses. They have a long cultural association with the Dalat people.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.
The Igidujin are a nomadic people from the Plain of Horses, poised between Faerûn and Kara-Tur.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.
The T'aghur are a nomadic people from the Plain of Horses in the Hordelands.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Tsu-Tsu are a semi-settled culture from the Plain of Horses. They originated as a rebel group of Fankiang, but are nowadays treated as their own distinct group.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Chukien people are the inhabitants of the Shou province of Chukei, which was the heart of old Shou Lung. The prevalence of red and brown hair among the Chukien sets them apart from their neighbours.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou

The human Chultan people, sometimes also sharing the name Tabaxi with the famed catfolk, originated in Katashaka in very distant times. They were led to safety in Chult by coatls who introduced them to the benevolent primordial Ubtao.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Tabaxi

The albino Chultan Dwarves, as distinct from their neighbours the Wild Dwarves, live in an underground realm known as the Domain, and support themselves with trade and mining.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dwarvish\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

The cloud giants, or Skyejotunen, are giants who typically make their homes on high mountain-tops or in enchanged cloud castles. They often live lives of luxury, creating and collecting works of art.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotun
Constructs are synthetic life-forms, some made by mortal artifice, and others by the power of the gods and the outer planes.
Copper dragons usually dwell in dry upland areas, and have a reputation as pranksters and patrons of the arts.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The Cormyrean people are a largely human culture based in the Forest Kingdom of Cormyr, which was settled by pioneers from Impiltur and Chondath in the years just after the raising of the Standing Stone in neighbouring Cormanthyr.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chondathan

Cornugons, or horned devils, are commonly junior officers in the Blood War armies of the baatezu, directing companies of lesser fiends and conscripted mortals under the orders of pit fiends.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal

The Crinti are largely half-drow, the descendants of human priestesses of Loviatar and drow from T'lindhet who allied to defeat the Arkaiuns and gain ascendancy over Dambrath.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dambrathan\n§Y*§! Access to the Tanistry succession.

Crystal dragons commonly live in icefields or on frozen mountain-tops, but are said to love the company of other creatures and to travel far in order to socialise and exercise their curiosity.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The Dalesfolk are the inhabitants of the Dalelands, whose forebears gained the right to settle in the open spaces among the forests of Cormanthyr by treaty with the elves, and raised the Standing Stone to mark this pact in 1 DR, the Year of Sunrise.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chondathan

The Damaran people are largely descended from the humans of Low Netheril, along with those from what was once Jhaamdath and the dwarves of Tethyamar. They mainly dwell in the cold lands of Damara and the Bloodstone Lands, but also spread into neighbouring regions.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Damaran
Many peoples are descended from the humans of Low Netheril, who scattered eastward to the lands around Damara when the archwizard Karsus destroyed High Netheril in his hubris.

The dark elves, in the broad sense, include all the descendants of the elves of ancient Ilythiir and Miyeritar, which were destroyed in the Crown Wars millennia ago. Many of them were cursed by the victorious sun elves, and driven into the Underdark where they were known as drow.
The modern dark elves arise from magical attempts to reverse the sun elf curse and restore to the drow the peaceful life that was stolen from them.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish

The Deep Imaskari people were the descendants of suvivors of the fall of ancient Imaskar to the Mulan people and the monstrous Phaerimm. They lived in underground enclaves for centuries before starting to emerge into Faerûn once more.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Roushoum
The goblins who dwell in and around the ancient Netherese mining complex of Dekanter tend to be stronger and fiercer than others, and many have unusual horns.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ghukliak

The Derro are a secretive community of subterranean dwarves, said to have been freed from illithid captivity by a strange and capricious god, and widely rumoured to be afflicted with insanity and strange visions.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dwarvish\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
The desert giants live mainly as nomads in the wilds of Zakhara. But their own legends tell of a time when they built great cities, which were taken from them by the jann.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
A dracolich is an undead dragon, animated by a specialised ritual devised by Sammaster, the fallen chosen of Mystra, and disseminated by the Cult of the Dragon.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic
Dragons are among the most ancient intelligent creatures of Faerûn, and the most diverse. All are huge winged lizards, but they vary greatly in habitat, abilities, and temperament.
Draegloths are four-armed drow-demon hybrids, usually conceived as part of the rituals of Lolth the Spider Queen.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Drowic
The Draeven people live around the shores of the Dragonmere at the western end of the Sea of Fallen Stars, and in the Western Heartlands beyond.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorasta

Dragons are among the most ancient intelligent creatures of Faerûn, and the most diverse. All are huge winged lizards, but they vary greatly in habitat, abilities, and temperament.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic
The first known dragonborn on Toril in modern times were those created ritually from willing humanoids of other species by devotees of Bahamut the Platinum Dragon.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Dragonborn, and their close kind the dragonspawn, are humanoids drawn from the same ancient ancestral stock that gave rise to the true dragons. Many of them were enslaved to the dragon overlords of Abeir for countless generations.

The most widespread drow group, the Udadrow are also the most notorious owing to their leaders' frequent devotion to the Abyssal powers, especially Lolth. But many of them shun this fanaticism and seek other paths.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Drowic

The Aevendrow, or Starlight Elves, are a rare drow group that lives mainly in secrecy in arctic regions of Faerûn, seeking an alternative to the wars and fanaticism that beset their kinfolk.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Drowic

The Lorendrow, or Greenshadow Elves, are a small drow group which fled from the cataclysm that drove their cousins underground, moving instead to southern jungles where they largely live in seclusion.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Drowic

The D'tarig are a hardy community of herders and traders most often encountered in the desert of Anauroch. They are short of stature, and some believe them to be descended from Low Netherese humans and the dwarves of Tethyamar.\n§ZCourt Language§!: D'tarig

Descended from a dwarven clan in old Shanatar who were enslaved by illithids, the duergar or gray dwarves are seen as dour, serious, and possessed of an unremittingly bleak and pitiless outlook.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dwarvish\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
The Durpari people come from the trading hubs of Durpar and the surrounding lands on the Golden Water in the far southeast of Faerûn.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Durpari

The Duskers hail from the Dusk Ports in the southwest of Laerakond, originally on Abeir. The Dusk Ports are thriving mercantile cities, but for many years they have existed in the shadow of Laerakond's mighty dragon overlords.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorass

Dwarves, also known as the Deep Folk, are stocky humanoids commonly associated with underground habitats and fine handicrafts. They have lived on Toril and Abeir since time immemorial, and their cultures span both worlds.
Earth genasi, sometimes called earthsouls, are people with ancestral ties to the Elemental Plane of Earth, and its residents such as dao.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Terran

The einheriar are immortal planar beings from upper planes such as Arcadia. Those encountered on the Material Plane are usually members of organised warbands serving the divine powers.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial
The fey eladrin, or noble eladrin, are elves whose ties to Faerie lend their bodies the power to shift with their emotions, reflecting the moods of the world's seasons.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish

The fey elves, sometimes called eladrin after their distant celestial relations, are elves who have maintained their ancestral connections to the mysterious otherworld known as the Feywild, or Faerie.

The high elves are a collection of elven cultures whose forebears came from Faerie, or the Feywild, in ancient times to establish mighty empire on Toril. Some view themselves as close to their fey elf kin who still partially reside in Faerie, while others think of themselves as wholly distinct.
Emerald dragons commonly live in warm climates. They are said to be fascinated by history and humanoid customs, but paranoid and unwilling to share their discoveries.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic
Equinals are horse-like guardinals, celestials from the Blessed Fields of Elysium.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

The Eraka are a collection of horse-riding tribes native to the Ride region, north of the Dragonspine Mountains. They are seen as fiercely independent, and possess an ancestral connection to the Ulutiun peoples of Pelvuria.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Erakic

The Eshowe are a rare subgroup of the Chultan people who were led from Katashaka to Chult by the coatls. After settling in Chult, the Eshowe were betrayed and slaughtered by their own tutelary god, Eshowdow. Few now remain compared to their height.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Tabaxi

The Numtanajd people of the highlands of Zakhara are habitual pastoralists, keeping sheep in mountain foothills alongside the nomadic Badia. They have many distinctive traditions, governing everything from getting out of bed to marriage and veiling.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
The fey are a diverse collection of beings native to the mystical otherworld known as the Feywild. On Toril, they often dwell in forests and other wild places.

The Fey'ri, also known as Daemonfey, are the descendants of ancient sun elves and demons from the abyss, created during the Crown Wars as an attempt to strengthen the ruling lines of Cormanthor and Siluvanede.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish

The Ffolk are the historical main human cultural group of the Moonshae Isles. They are descended from the ancient Talfir of the Chionthar Valley region in Faerûn.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Waelan\n§Y*§! Access to the Tanistry succession.

Fiends are immortal outsiders from the Lower Outer Planes. The two largest groups of fiends, the baatezu and the tanar'ri, are locked in an aeons-old conflict known as the Blood War, in which other groups such as yugoloths intervene for their own benefit.
Fire giants, or Ildjotunen, live in hot regions, especially around volcanoes. They are known as expert crafters, but they also have a reputation for cruelty and slavery.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotun
Fire genasi, sometimes called flamesouls, are people with ancestral ties to the Elemental Plane of Fire, and its residents such as efreet.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ignan

Firenewts, also known as salamen, are a variety of lizardfolk who are specialised to live in volcanic regions. They have a reputation cruelty and treachery, and many of them worship the elemental powers Kossuth and Imix.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
The seas and lakes of Toril are home to many sentient fish-like species, some of whom become involved in the business of land-dwellers.
Flinds are a variety of gnoll noted for their physical stature and distinctive martial traditions.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gnoll

Fomorians are a variety of giant who were once forest-dwellers like their cousins the Voadkyn, but were cursed and driven underground after the god Karontor led them in an attempted conquest of the Feywild.
§ZCourt Language§!: Jotun
§Y*§! Access to the Open succession.
§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
§Y*§! Cannot take arcane classes.

Forest gnomes are a rare and habitually reclusive gnomish sub-culture who prefer to live in isolation in remote woodlands. They generally have little connection to outsiders, even other gnomes, unless driven to travel by external pressures.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gnim

Frost giants, or Isejotunen, dwell on high mountains and glaciers, and in parts of the polar regions of Toril. They are renowned as warriors, but have a reputation for ignorance and poor social skills.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotun\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

Gehreleths, also known as demodands, are fiends from the Tarterian Depths of Carceri. On their home plane they serve as jailers to a range of supernatural captives, and when they are summoned to the Material Plane, it is often to serve as guards of some kind.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Demodand

Gelugons, otherwise known as ice devils, are a variety of baatezu native to the coldest parts of Baator, such as Cania and Stygia. They serve as senior commanders in the Blood War, answering directly to the pit fiends.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal

Gem dragons are noted for their glittering scales, their psychic prowess, and their general philosophical indifference to good and evil. Many of them are reclusive, but some choose to live close beside other species in order to study them.
Genasi are human-like creatures whose ancestry includes creatures native to the elemental planes, especially genies.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Primordial

Genies are powerful elemental beings, most of whom are native to the elemental Inner Planes. Their highest nobles are famed for the ability to grant wishes, and they have intervened in Toril's history many times in the past.

The Ghostwise halflings split from their kinfolk in ancient Luiren when they adopted the worship of the fierce god Malar. Although most of them have long since recanted this practice, they still lead largely separate lives. They have distinctive cultural practices, including knowledge of barbarian warrior paths and esoteric psychic disciplines.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Luiric

The Jotunbrud, sometimes known as the True Giants, are gigantic humanoids who claim descent from their supreme deity, Annam All-Father. Most of them hold to the sacred traditions of the Ordning, which impart a distinctive set of moral values to giantkind.

The gith are a human-like species who take their name from the ancient liberator Gith, who freed them from ages-long enslavement by the mind flayers. Not native to Toril, they dwell mostly in distant cosmic realms, and only come to the surface world to pursue their ancestral vendettas.

Githvyrik is the name given to those who refused to take a side in the great schism between Gith and Zerthimon after the fall of the mind flayer empire. Many githvyrik live as pirates in Wildspace, while a few, including the most ancient members of the culture, are solitary psychic warriors with private esoteric philosophies.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gith

Githyanki is the name given to those who remained loyal to Gith the Liberator when Zerthimon rebelled against her. Gith and her successor Vlaakith the First led the githyanki to dwell in the timeless void of the Astral Plane, where they are visited by their sworn allies, the red dragons.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gith

Githzerai is the name given to those who sided with Zerthimon when he challenged Gith's leadership of her liberated people. Zerthimon and his heir, Zaerith Menyar-ag-Gith, led the githzerai to the swirling plane of Limbo, where they became anarchs, masters of chaos-shaping.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gith

The Gontese are a mixed human and dragonborn culture of Laerakond descended from the pioneers who settled around the Glaur Barrens in the wake of the Blue Breath of Change.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Gnolls are hyenalike humanoids who roam open plains across Toril. In ancient times many of them worshipped a god called Gorellik. But with the passage of time, the demon lord Yeenoghu became the principal deity of the gnolls, and it was even rumoured that he would create new, more faithful gnolls by magically converting wild hyenas.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gnoll\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
The Beastfolk of Toril are many and varied. Their origins are largely lost to history, and it may be that many of them lived in the wild parts of the land before orcs and modern humans appeared.

Rock gnomes are the commonest gnomish culture, and can be found throughout much of Faerun and Zakhara. They live mainly in small towns, and are noted for their ingenuity and sense of fun.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gnim

Gnomes are diminutive humanoids, smaller than most other humanoids except halflings. They are sometimes called the Forgotten Folk, but they are found alongside humans throughout the material world and the Feywild.

Goblins are the physically smallest of the group of cultures and species to which they give their name, but also by far the most numerous. Goblins can be found in practically every climate, either in villages of their own, or alongside their larger kin, or orc and humans. Exiled from their ancestral home in the Feywild, they are seen as both foolish and cunning - a paradox which reflects their great diversity and adaptability.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ghukliak

There are many kinds of goblinoid, some of which are too rare to form independent cultures. They are distinguished by their hardiness, their ability to adapt to many climates, and their ancient roots in the Feywild.

Among the most powerful of dragons, gold dragons are renowned for their wisdom and insight. They can dwell in almost any environment, and some a rumoured to walk among other species in magical disguises.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Gold dwarves, also known as Hill Dwarves, are a widespread dwarven culture whose traditional homeland is the Great Rift, a vast canyon and cavern complex at the heart of the plains of the Shaar. They traditionally put great store in material wealth and family honour, but the pressures of life in the Rift lead many to strike out on other paths.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dwarvish\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
Golems are synthetic life-forms animated by powerful sacred magic.

Gol-Kaa, sometimes called Goliaths by outsiders, are among the smallest of the giants. Commonly associated with the cultures of their larger cousins, they also form communities of their own in remote or mountainous regions.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotun

Gray orcs were brought from another world millennia ago by the theurgist Thayd. After their defeat in the Orcgate Wars, they scattered across much of northern and eastern Faerun, often forming small nomadic communities.\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Daraktan

Green dragons, also known as forest dragons, usually dwell in woodlands, although some compete with black dragons for territory in swamps. They are known as conniving manipulators, fond of elaborate personal schemes.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Green elves, also known as wild elves or grugach, live mostly apart from other elven civilisation. Compared to their close kin the wood elves, they live a more nomadic lifestyle, and to favour empheral artforms such as music over visual arts and architecture.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish

column2: A Sahuagin Warrior is the bane of all underwater life. Ever hungry, ever vicious, and eager to earn glory, they'll rather die fighting than retreat.

Veterans of many battles, the Sahuagin Baron knows their position is still precarious. Often the pawn of their Princes and target of ambitious Chiefs, they seldom live long.
Having witnessed the fall of many heroes and foolish adventurers, a Sahuagin Prince fears little besides the machinations of their own underlings.
A warlord whose power reaches the farthest depths, this creature recalls the fall of kingdoms. A Sahuagin King is rarely seen, though their is often the woe of all surface dwellers.

A Sahuagin Emperor is a legendary creature to behold, for their memory recalls when Toril was young, and the sea fresh. Few things can challenge this monster in battle, save for True giants and Kraken.
